channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Death in Navy SEAL Training Exposes a Culture of Brutality, Cheating and Drugs
item.description: The elite force’s selection course is so punishing that few make it through, and many of those who do resort to illicit tactics.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Trade Tanks and Artillery on the Front Line
item.description: Most of the bartering involves items captured from Russian troops, which are exchanged for urgently needed supplies. “Let’s just call it a simplification of bureaucracy,” one soldier said.
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Repairing a captured Russian armored personnel carrier in the Donetsk region of Ukraine last week.

item.title: U.N. Nuclear Inspectors Are in Ukraine to Visit the Zaporizhzhia Plant
item.description: As artillery strikes continued near the complex, the inspectors could reach the nuclear plant as soon as Wednesday
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant was shrouded in smoke on Monday, as fires burned amid the sounds of near-constant shelling.

item.title: How German Companies Are Staring Down Putin’s Threat to Cut Off Gas
item.description: Industrial producers across Germany are coming up with unique ways to cut their dependence on natural gas as Russia’s war in Ukraine keeps prices high.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A power plant burning coal in Wilhelmshaven, Germany. Coal-fired plants, many of which were destined to be shut down, have been revived by manufacturers seeking an alternative to expensive Russian natural gas.

item.title: The Animal Translators
item.description: Scientists are using machine learning to eavesdrop on naked mole rats, fruit bats, crows and whales — and to communicate back.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Naked mole rats live in large, underground colonies and have an elaborate vocal repertoire.

item.title: Trump Request for Special Master Could Open Door for Delays to Investigation
item.description: The former president, who used the slow pace of litigation to run out the clock on congressional oversight, is seeking intervention that could lead to appeals and slow the documents inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department said in a court filing that it had completed a detailed analysis of all the documents retrieved from former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida residence, Mar-a-Lago.

item.title: Gov. Kathy Hochul Seeks Donations From Cuomo Appointees
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s campaign says contributions from board and commission members and their families are fair game because she did not appoint them.
item.dc:creator: Jay Root
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s willingness to raise money from appointees runs counter to her pledge that her administration would represent a clean break from her predecessor’s.

item.title: A Surprise Senate Race in Colorado: Michael Bennet and Joe O’Dea
item.description: Senator Michael Bennet, a Democrat seeking re-election in Colorado, faces a challenge from Joe O’Dea, a novice Republican emphasizing more moderate positions in a break with his party.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Rachel Woolf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Michael Bennet, second from left, speaking to constituents in Steamboat Springs, Colo. He is seeking a third full term in a state that has been trending Democratic.

item.title: Trump and Abortion Shift Narrative for Midterm Elections
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Democrats had been struggling to make Donald Trump the prime villain in their election narrative. He made it easy by bursting back into the news.

item.title: Biden to Focus on ‘Battle for the Soul of the Nation’ in Prime-Time Speech
item.description: The president is set to return to his campaign theme of democracy in peril as his party fights to retain its hold on Congress in the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s speech is also expected to emphasize the reputation of the United States on the global stage.

item.title: This Remote Mine Could Foretell the Future of America’s Electric Car Industry
item.description: Hiding a thousand feet below the earth’s surface in this patch of northern Minnesota wetlands are ancient mineral deposits that some view as critical to fueling America’s clean energy future.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tim Gruber
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times

item.title: Serena Williams Wins First-Round Match Over Danka Kovinic at US Open
item.description: Williams will face the tournament’s No. 2 seed, Anett Kontaveit of Estonia, on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams won, 6-3, 6-3, over Danka Kovinic of Montenegro.

item.title: Serena Williams Rises to the Occasion, Like So Many Times Before
item.description: Williams met a valedictory night at the U.S. Open with a win that was fitting, and with a second-round match on Wednesday, the farewell party at Arthur Ashe Stadium continues.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams celebrating her win over Danka Kovinic on Monday night.

item.title: Serena Williams Keeps Focus Amid the Fanfare
item.description: A star-studded crowd inside Arthur Ashe Stadium was joined by throngs of fans outside during Williams’s first-round U.S. Open match.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Sarah Stier/Getty Images
item.media:description: Fans cheered for Serena Williams of the United States after she won a point against Danka Kovinic of Montenegro. The night session Monday set an attendance record.

item.title: In Brazil, the Last Member of an Isolated Indigenous Tribe Dies
item.description: Known as the “Man of the Hole,” the last member of an Indigenous group was found dead this month, marking the first recorded disappearance of an isolated tribe in the country.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Funai/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A still image from a video provided by the Brazilian government showing one of the huts built by the “Man of the Hole” in Rondônia State in 2018.

item.title: It’s Not Just You — Blank Street Coffee Is Suddenly Inescapable
item.description: Built around high-volume automated espresso systems, the rapidly expanding coffee shop has caught the attention of skeptical New Yorkers.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.media:description: In just two years, the Blank Street coffee chain expanded from this tiny cart to 40 locations in New York City and five in London.

item.title: Why I Changed My Mind on Student Debt Forgiveness
item.description: Our current system of student loans and college funding is at odds with what we hope to achieve by encouraging people to go to college.
item.dc:creator: Susan Dynarski
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by Nay Ni Ratn Mak Can Thuk/EyeEm, via Getty Images

item.title: What It’s Like to Have Face Blindness
item.description: When you can’t rely on facial recognition, you look beyond the obvious.
item.dc:creator: James Robinson

item.title: What Bill Barr Did to Clear Trump Is Still a Danger
item.description: The ability to investigate future high-level wrongdoing in the executive branch is at stake.
item.dc:creator: Neal K. Katyal
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump and Attorney General Bill Barr in 2019.

item.title: Ted Cruz Would Like to Put Some Words in Your Mouth
item.description: The idea that student loan relief is a handout to a small minority of affluent college graduates is simply a myth.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times

item.title: I’m a Ukrainian Soldier, and I’ve Accepted My Death
item.description: So it must be for those who tread the path of war.
item.dc:creator: Artem Chekh
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mass burial in Bucha, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: The Book That Explains Our Cultural Stagnation
item.description: Art has gotten so boring. W. David Marx knows why.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Status and Culture: How Our Desire for Social Rank Creates Taste, Identity, Art, Fashion, and Constant Change (Book)
item.media:credit: Calla Kessler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Partygoers at Art Basel Miami Beach.

item.title: A Grammy-Nominated Singer Performs and Explores Music’s Deep Power Over Us
item.description: Allison Russell discusses — and demonstrates — the craft of songwriting and how to find ‘survivor’s joy’ through music.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
item.media:credit: Marc Baptiste

item.title: Donald Trump’s Death Grip Has Upended the G.O.P. Senate Map
item.description: Republicans seem to feel less feisty than when they were cruising into the summer.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: A Poorer Generation
item.description: Americans under 40 have had to cope with a worse economy than earlier generations. How should it affect the debate over Biden’s debt-relief plan?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Shawn Thew/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Student loan forgiveness advocates attend a press conference in front of the White House in Washington, DC, last week.

item.title: Inside the Adolescent Mental Health Crisis
item.description: Young people in the United States are facing a new set of risks. Why has the situation caught so many people off guard?
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Michael Simon Johnson, Rikki Novetsky, Stella Tan, Patricia Willens, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: C, a young person in Utah, started experiencing feelings of restlessness, depressions and anxiety as early as the third grade.

item.title: Introducing ‘The Run-Up,’ a Politics Podcast from The New York Times
item.description: The midterm elections are usually a referendum on the party in power. This year, they’re about so much more.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: How Will the Student Loan Forgiveness Plan Affect You?
item.description: We want to hear about what President Biden’s debt cancellation plan means for your life and finances.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times

item.title: Biden’s Student Loan Plan Sets Off Fierce Debate Among Economists
item.description: Liberals and more moderate Democrats are arguing over the impact on inflation, the federal budget deficit and high earners.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden announced his student loan forgiveness plan with Education Secretary Miguel A. Cardona last week.

item.title: Deadly Floods Devastate an Already Fragile Pakistan
item.description: More than 1,100 have died as record monsoon rains inundate the country, washing away bridges, roads and crop fields. Much of Pakistan is underwater.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Raymond Zhong and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Asim Tanveer/Associated Press
item.media:description: Army troops evacuated people from a flood-hit area in Rajanpur, Punjab district, Pakistan, on Saturday.

item.title: Iraq Cleric Muqtada al-Sadr Tries To Defuse Baghdad Clashes
item.description: The influential cleric Muqtada al-Sadr called for protesters to leave Baghdad’s Green Zone within an hour, after two days of violence that left many in Iraq fearing a new phase of political chaos.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Ahmad Al-Rubaye/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Armed members of Muqtada al-Sadr’s paramilitary organization during clashes with pro-Iranian Iraqi security forces in Baghdad’s Green Zone on Tuesday.

item.title: Lisa LaFlamme Ouster Sets Off Outcry in Canada
item.description: The chief executive of a Canadian news network pushed back against allegations that sex, age or gray hair were factors in the abrupt dismissal of the veteran journalist, Lisa LaFlamme.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: George Pimentel/The Canadian Press
item.media:description: Lisa LaFlamme after winning a Best News Anchor award in April.

item.title: Burnout vs Depression: How to Tell the Difference and Find Relief
item.description: Clinicians and researchers offer advice on how to tell the difference, and what to do about both.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: What Is Quiet Quitting and Who Is It For?
item.description: For those not ready to make a grand exit, a softer approach may work.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger
item.media:credit: Anthony Redpath – Getty Images

item.title: Work Burnout: How to Spot Symptoms and What to Do
item.description: Here’s how to recognize the physical symptoms of work-related stress — and what to do about them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Alva Skog

item.title: How to Beat Burnout — Without Quitting Your Job
item.description: We’re all feeling a little fried at work and home. But there are ways to stay sharp and recharge.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Zuckerman
item.media:credit: Tim Peacock

item.title: Exploring Spain’s Arab Influence
item.description: Exploring the country’s Arab influence is an impossibly romantic journey, involving palaces with intricate geometric designs, castles and grand mosques reconfigured by Christians into cathedrals.
item.dc:creator: Nina Burleigh
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Emilio Parra Doiztua for The New York Times
item.media:description: Córdoba’s Mosque-Cathedral, or La Mezquita, was one of the first and grandest mosques in Europe.
